GLocalFair: Jointly Improving Global and Local Group Fairness
in Federated Learning

Syed Irfan Ali Meerza1    Luyang Liu2    Jiaxin Zhang3    Jian Liu1
1University of Tennessee Knoxville
2Google Research
3Intuit AI Research
smeerza@vols.utk.edu, luyangliu@google.com, jxzhangai@gmail.com, jliu@utk.edu
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a prospective solution for collaboratively learning a shared model across clients without sacrificing their data privacy. However, the federated learned model tends to be biased against certain demographic groups (e.g., racial and gender groups) due to the inherent FL properties, such as data heterogeneity and party selection. Unlike centralized learning, mitigating bias in FL is particularly challenging as private training datasets and their sensitive attributes are typically not directly accessible. Most prior research in this field only focuses on global fairness while overlooking the local fairness of individual clients. Moreover, existing methods often require sensitive information about the client’s local datasets to be shared, which is not desirable. To address these issues, we propose GLocalFair, a client-server co-design fairness framework that can jointly improve global and local group fairness in FL without the need for sensitive statistics about the client’s private datasets. Specifically, we utilize constrained optimization to enforce local fairness on the client side and adopt a fairness-aware clustering-based aggregation on the server to further ensure the global model fairness across different sensitive groups while maintaining high utility. Experiments on two image datasets and one tabular dataset with various state-of-the-art fairness baselines show that GLocalFair can achieve enhanced fairness under both global and local data distributions while maintaining a good level of utility and client fairness.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) McMahan et al. (2017) allows multiple data holders (i.e., clients) to collaboratively train a global model under the coordination of a central server without directly sharing their private datasets. Its strong emphasis on client privacy has made it particularly attractive for many privacy-critical applications, such as speaker verification Granqvist et al. (2020), predictive typing Hard et al. (2018), image classification Chen and Chao (2021) and healthcare Rieke et al. (2020); Xu et al. (2021). Although providing great privacy benefits, the inherent characteristics of FL, such as data heterogeneity, party selection, and client dropping out, will inevitably make the resulting FL model biased against specific demographic groups (e.g., racial and gender groups), causing specific populations to receive undesirable treatments. Additionally, to protect clients’ privacy, in FL the server is prohibited from directly accessing the clients’ datasets, rendering most centralized bias mitigation strategies inapplicable Grgić-Hlača et al. (2018); Zhang et al. (2018); Lohia et al. (2019). Therefore, how to improve fairness has become an open problem in this field and has gained considerable research attention recently Kairouz et al. (2021).

Existing Efforts in Improving Fairness in FL. Initial studies Li et al. (2020); Mohri et al. (2019); Lyu et al. (2020); Li et al. (2021); Zhang et al. (2020b) in this field mainly focus on client fairness, which aims to promote equalized accuracies across all clients. This is typically achieved through reducing the client’s performance disparity Li et al. (2020) or maximizing the performance of the worst client Mohri et al. (2019). However, under such frameworks, the FL model can show similar accuracies on all clients while still being biased against certain under-represented groups. To address this, a few recent studies Abay et al. (2020); Zhang et al. (2020a); Rodríguez-Gálvez et al. (2021); Chu et al. (2021); Ezzeldin et al. (2023); Du et al. (2021) have proposed group fairness solutions for improving fairness across different sensitive groups. These studies mainly utilize deep multi-agent reinforcement learning Zhang et al. (2020a), re-weighing mechanisms Abay et al. (2020); Ezzeldin et al. (2023); Du et al. (2021), optimization with fairness constraints Chu et al. (2021) or the modified method of differential multipliers Rodríguez-Gálvez et al. (2021) to achieve group fairness in FL.

Limitations of Existing Group Fairness Research in FL. While the aforementioned group fairness approaches can improve FL fairness in certain cases, most of them Zhang et al. (2020a); Rodríguez-Gálvez et al. (2021); Chu et al. (2021); Du et al. (2021) only focus on achieving global fairness under the overall data distribution, without considering local fairness on individual clients. Due to the non-IID111IID: identically and independently distributed. nature of the client’s data in FL, local distribution at a specific client may not reflect the exact global data distribution. Thus, merely achieving global fairness cannot provide guarantees of local fairness. In practice, this could result in emergent group unfairness at individual clients due to the client’s “non-IIDness” in FL. Figure 1 provides an illustrative example of the difference between global group fairness and local group fairness. To further illustrate, let’s consider a cross-silo FL scenario where image classifiers for brain tumor detection are trained across several hospitals with distinct patient demographic compositions. In such a case, local fairness is more important since the model will eventually be deployed at each client and thus would directly affect the model’s diagnosis accuracy Cui et al. (2021). To the best of our knowledge, only a few studies Abay et al. (2020); Ezzeldin et al. (2023) attempt to address the local group fairness issue. However, they all require clients to share sensitive statistics (e.g., data sample counts per sensitive group or group-specific positive prediction rates), which would raise privacy concerns. Additionally, they rely on either reweighing or debiasing-based mechanisms to ensure local fairness, which will be heavily influenced by the distribution of local datasets, thus they may only achieve suboptimal fairness with highly heterogeneous datasets in FL.

To circumvent the aforementioned limitations, in this paper, we propose GLocalFair, the first client-server co-design fairness framework that can jointly improve global and local group fairness to learn a fair global model on both local datasets of individual clients and the global dataset. Specifically, to ensure local fairness, we pose the classification task on each client as a constrained optimization problem with a constraint that maximizes the true-positive rate (TPR) of sensitive groups and minimizes the false-positive rate (FPR). We then transform the constrained optimization problem into a two-player zero-sum game. To ensure global group fairness, we incorporate a clustering-based aggregation method on the server side. Specifically, we cluster the client updates based on their fairness level measure using the Gini Coefficient Gini (1912) and calculate a weighted mean within each cluster, based on their dataset size, to update the global model. We believe such two-layer fairness strategies can ensure enhanced model fairness at both global and local levels.

Our framework brings several benefits over existing methods: (1) Improved Data Privacy: In GLocalFair, the server assigns weight to client updates using a clustering algorithm. This way does not require the server to have access to any information about each client’s sensitive local dataset; (2) Customizable Fairness Configuration on Client Model: By adopting constrained optimization at the client’s side, our framework provides the client with the freedom to choose which fairness metric (FPR or TPR) to emphasize locally. For instance, in the brain tumor diagnosis application, it is more expensive to falsely classify a tumor case as healthy (false negative) than to diagnose a healthy person as malignant (false positive); and (3) Multiple Sensitive Attributes: Leveraging constrained optimization, our framework can be naturally generalized to the scenario with multiple sensitive attributes by incorporating additional constraints.

We conduct extensive experiments involving multiple federated datasets, including image, and tabular data formats, and various state-of-the-art FL fairness baselines, such as group-fairness studies FairFed Ezzeldin et al. (2023) and FedFB Zeng et al. (2022), and client-fairness studies q-FFL Li et al. (2020) and GIFAIR Yue et al. (2023). The results demonstrate that GLocalFair can achieve enhanced fairness under both global and local data distributions while maintaining a good level of model utility and client fairness.

2 Related Work

Client Fairness in Federated Learning. The goal of client fairness is to diminish the performance difference of models across different clients (known as the client parity). To achieve this, Li et al. Li et al. (2020) propose q-Fair Federated Learning (q-FFL), an algorithm that aims to encourage a uniform accuracy distribution across all clients by re-weighting the clients according to their local empirical loss. Mohri et al. Mohri et al. (2019) propose an agnostic federated learning framework to maximize the performance of the worst-performing client. GIFAIR Yue et al. (2023) leverages a regularization to penalize spread in client loss for uniform performance. Differently, Ditto Li et al. (2021) seeks to reduce a client’s performance variance through personalization. In addition, there are some other studies Lyu et al. (2020); Zhang et al. (2020b) aiming to achieve proportional fairness that allows clients with higher contributions to be rewarded with a better-performing local model. Despite improving client disparity, these methods still fail to address the discrimination against certain demographic groups in the FL scenario due to the high data heterogeneity across clients.

Group Fairness in Federated Learning. A better practice of responsible AI is group fairness, which requires the model to treat different demographic groups defined by the sensitive attribute (e.g., race and gender) equally. Several recent studies have explored group fairness in the FL setting from the global fairness perspective. In particular, FairFL Zhang et al. (2020a), AgnosticFair Du et al. (2021), FCFL Cui et al. (2021), and FedFB Zeng et al. (2022) propose to achieve global group fairness by incorporating fairness constraints into objective functions. However, this requires clients to share sensitive statistical information with the server. Beyond global fairness, only a few studies have tackled the local fairness issue by designing fairness mechanisms on the client side or the server side. For instance, Abay et al. Abay et al. (2020) propose to adopt centralized fair learning strategies by applying debiasing mechanisms locally on each client. Unfortunately, this method would be less effective if the client’s sensitive attribute distributions are highly heterogeneous, making it unfavorable in practical scenarios. FairFed Ezzeldin et al. (2023) can adaptively modify the aggregation weights on the server side according to the mismatch between the server’s global fairness measure and the client’s local fairness measure. However, this method requires the statistics from the client’s private datasets to be shared at the start of the training. Differently, in this paper, we propose a client-server co-design framework in FL for jointly improving global and local group fairness regarding multiple sensitive attributes without requiring clients to share any sensitive information about their local datasets.

3 Primer on Federated Learning and Fairness

3.1 Federated Learning

The goal of FL is to collaboratively train a global machine-learning model among a large number of distributed clients under the coordination of a central server without accessing client data. Let θ𝜃\theta denote the learned parameters of the global model, then the main objective of FL is to solve:

min𝜃​f​(θ)=∑k=1npk​Lk​(θ),Lk=1dk​∑jk=1dkljk​(θ),formulae-sequence𝜃𝑓𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐿𝑘𝜃subscript𝐿𝑘1subscript𝑑𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘1subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑙subscript𝑗𝑘𝜃\footnotesize\underset{\theta}{\min}\quad f(\theta)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}p_{k}L_{k}(\theta),\quad L_{k}=\frac{1}{d_{k}}\sum_{j_{k}=1}^{d_{k}}l_{j_{k}}(\theta), (1)

where n𝑛n is the total number of clients. For the k𝑘k-th client, pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} denotes the probability of its participation in the current training round (∑k=1npk=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{n}p_{k}=1). Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k} is the empirical loss over its local data where ljksubscript𝑙subscript𝑗𝑘l_{j_{k}} is the loss on the j𝑗j-th sample of the k𝑘k-th client, and dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} is the number of local data samples. The majority of studies solve the optimization problem formulated in Equation 1 by choosing a selection of clients, each with probability pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} at each round and then executing an optimizer such as stochastic gradient descent (SGD) for several iterations locally at each client. FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017) is a commonly used approach for solving Equation 1 in non-convex settings. The approach works simply by applying E𝐸E epochs of SGD locally at each chosen client and then averaging the resulting local models. Unfortunately, this approach introduces highly inconsistent performance between different clients. Specifically, the resulting global model can be biased toward the clients with a greater volume of data points or those who frequently engage in the training process. Additionally, naive averaging can result in a global model that is biased against certain demographic groups presented in the dataset.

3.2 Fairness Notion

In client fairness, if the performance of model-a on the n𝑛n clients is more uniform than the performance of model-b on the n𝑛n clients, we informally state that model-a provides a fairer solution than model-b. For group fairness, the model performance is measured with respect to how it performs compared to the underlying groups defined by sensitive attribute G𝐺G. If a model performs equally for the privileged group G=1𝐺1G=1 and the underprivileged group G=0𝐺0G=0, then the model is fair through the group fairness lens. Formally, given data sample X𝑋X and its corresponding label Y𝑌Y, for a model with binary prediction Y^^𝑌\hat{Y}, we consider the following two metrics to quantify its group fairness:

Demographic Parity Dwork et al. (2012): If a classifier’s prediction Y^^𝑌\hat{Y} is statistically independent of G𝐺G, it meets demographic parity under a distribution (X,G,Y)𝑋𝐺𝑌(X,G,Y). This is equivalent to 𝔼​[Y^|G=a]=𝔼​[Y^]𝔼delimited-[]conditional^𝑌𝐺𝑎𝔼delimited-[]^𝑌\mathbb{E}[\hat{Y}|G=a]=\mathbb{E}[\hat{Y}], where a=0𝑎0a=0 or 111 for a binary group. Demographic parity can also be measured by the Demographic Parity Difference (DPD), with P​r​(⋅)𝑃𝑟⋅Pr(\cdot) denoting the probability:

DPD=|Pr(Y^=1|G=1)−Pr(Y^=1|G=0)|.\footnotesize{\textup{DPD}=\left|Pr(\hat{Y}=1|G=1)-Pr(\hat{Y}=1|G=0)\right|.} (2)

Equalized Odds Hardt et al. (2016): If a classifier satisfies equalized odds, its predictions Y^^𝑌\hat{Y} are conditionally independent of G𝐺G given the true label Y𝑌Y under a distribution (X,G,Y)𝑋𝐺𝑌(X,G,Y). Mathematically, this can be expressed as 𝔼​[Y^|G=a,Y=1]=𝔼​[Y^|Y=1]𝔼delimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditional^𝑌𝐺𝑎𝑌1𝔼delimited-[]conditional^𝑌𝑌1\mathbb{E}[\hat{Y}|G=a,Y=1]=\mathbb{E}[\hat{Y}|Y=1], where a𝑎a represents a sensitive group. In other words, a model satisfies equalized odds if the probability of a true positive and the probability of a false positive are the same across different sensitive groups. Equalized odds can be formulated as:

Pr(Y^=1|Y=y,G=1)=Pr(Y^=1|Y=y,G=0).\footnotesize{Pr(\hat{Y}=1|Y=y,G=1)=Pr(\hat{Y}=1|Y=y,G=0).} (3)

3.3 Global and Local Group Fairness

Clients in FL generally have non-IID data distributions. To account for this data heterogeneity, we further consider two levels of fairness: global and local group fairness. The global fairness performance of a given model considers the entire dataset across the n𝑛n clients who participate in FL, whereas the local fairness performance is determined by only applying the fairness metrics described in Equations 2 and 3 to the local dataset Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} at client k𝑘k. Because of the non-IID characteristics of the local data distributions, the overall global data distribution may not be well represented by a single local distribution at any of the clients. As a result, only mitigating the fairness issue on each client may not improve global fairness. And vice versa, improving global fairness may not ensure local fairness for each client. To balance local and global fairness, we propose a method that can jointly mitigate the bias in the trained model, addressing both the individual client’s local datasets and the full datasets spanning all participating clients.

4 Design of GLocalFair

4.1 Design Overview

Due to the inherent data heterogeneity in FL, the distribution of local datasets on individual clients may be highly distinct from the distribution of the full dataset across all participating clients. Thus, merely achieving global fairness cannot provide a guarantee of local fairness. To solve this challenge, we propose a client-server co-design fairness framework, GLocalFair, to jointly improve both global and local group fairness. As shown in Figure 2, we consider n𝑛n clients that collaboratively train a global model. On the client side, we use constrained optimization to ensure equitable performance of the shared global model across each sensitive group present in the local datasets. Specifically, in communication round t𝑡t, all participating clients first download the current global model (θg​l​o​b​a​ltsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙\theta^{t}_{global}) from the central server and then compute local model updates on their local datasets, with constraints to minimize False Positive Rate (FPR) and False Negative Rate (FNR) to values below preset thresholds set by τFNRsubscript𝜏FNR\tau_{\textup{FNR}} and τFPRsubscript𝜏FPR\tau_{\textup{FPR}}. Next, the clients upload their model updates (θktsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k}^{t}, k∈{1,..,n}k\in\left\{1,..,n\right\}) to the server to participate in the federated training. On the server side, we employ K-means clustering to group the client updates based on their Gini coefficients Gini (1912), which serve as a fairness proxy. Subsequently, the updates of each cluster are aggregated, where the weight assigned to each update is proportional to the amount of data utilized to train the local model. Then, the aggregated updates undergo another round of aggregation, where a set of weights w^1,…​w^nsubscript^𝑤1…subscript^𝑤𝑛{\hat{w}_{1},...\hat{w}_{n}} is assigned based on their cumulative Gini coefficient value, favoring updates that exhibit greater fairness. This results in a more balanced and fair distribution of updates. The resulting aggregated update is then used to update the global model, leading to a more equitable and unbiased model (θg​l​o​b​a​lt+1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝑡1\theta_{global}^{t+1}). Finally, this updated model is sent back to the clients in the next round, ensuring that all participants benefit from the fairness improvements gained on both the server and client sides.

4.2 Local Fairness by Imposing Constraints

4.2.1 Local Fairness Constraints

To ensure local fairness (e.g., group fairness of the learned model θktsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\theta^{t}_{k} on the k𝑘k-th client’s local dataset), we propose a constrained optimization-based approach that is employed on each client. Specifically, in GLocalFair, the fairness problem is recast as a problem of minimizing an empirical loss while adhering to one or more fairness constraints. We constrain the model with two fairness metrics, namely, False Negative Equality Difference (FNED) and False Positive Equality Difference (FPED),

Thus, the binary classification task, incorporating fairness constraints to mitigate unintended bias, can be formulated as follows:

minθkt∈Θ​1dk​∑X∈DkfL​(X;θkt),s.t.max{FNRG1,..}−FNRo​v​e​r​a​l​l<τFNR⋅FNRo​v​e​r​a​l​l−min⁡{FNRG1,⋯}<τFNR⋅max⁡{FPRG1,⋯}−FPRo​v​e​r​a​l​l<τFPR⋅FPRo​v​e​r​a​l​l−min⁡{FPRG1,⋯}​<τFPR,\footnotesize\begin{split}&\underset{\theta_{k}^{t}\in\Theta}{\min}\quad\frac{1}{d_{k}}\sum_{X\in D_{k}}f_{L}(X;\theta_{k}^{t}),\\ &\textup{s.t.}\quad\max\{\textup{FNR}_{G_{1}},..\}-\textup{FNR}_{overall}\\ &<\tau_{\textup{FNR}}\cdot\textup{FNR}_{overall}-\min\{\textup{FNR}_{G_{1}},\cdots\}\\ &<\tau_{\textup{FNR}}\cdot\max\{\textup{FPR}_{G_{1}},\cdots\}-\textup{FPR}_{overall}\\ &<\tau_{\textup{FPR}}\cdot\textup{FPR}_{overall}-\min\{\textup{FPR}_{G_{1}},\cdots\}\text{\footnotesize$<\tau_{\textup{FPR}}$},\end{split}\normalsize (4)

where fLsubscript𝑓𝐿f_{L} is the binary cross-entropy loss that we want to minimize, Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is the local dataset, and θktsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k}^{t} is the local model of client k𝑘k at t𝑡tth communication round and τFNRsubscript𝜏FNR\tau_{\textup{FNR}} and τFPRsubscript𝜏FPR\tau_{\textup{FPR}} are the allowed deviations from overall FNRs and FPRs, respectively, FNRo​v​e​r​a​l​lsubscriptFNR𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑎𝑙𝑙\textup{FNR}_{overall} and FPRo​v​e​r​a​l​lsubscriptFPR𝑜𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑎𝑙𝑙\textup{FPR}_{overall} are the false negative and false positive rates on the entire local dataset, respectively, and FNRGpsubscriptFNRsubscript𝐺𝑝\textup{FNR}_{G_{p}} and FPRGpsubscriptFPRsubscript𝐺𝑝\textup{FPR}_{G_{p}} represent the corresponding rates in the group Gpsubscript𝐺𝑝G_{p}.

4.2.2 Constraint Optimization

Solving the constrained problem in Equation 4 presents significant challenges due to the data-dependent nature of the constraints, which leads to high computational costs for verification. Furthermore, the constraints represent a linear combination of indicators, rendering them non-sub-differentiable with respect to θktsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k}^{t}. The problem with constraints outlined in Equation 4 can be resolved through the following alternative approach:

minθkt∈Θ​1dk​∑X∈DkfL​(X;θkt)+∑i=1mλi​gi​(θkt),superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡Θ1subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑋subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑓𝐿𝑋superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\footnotesize{\underset{\theta_{k}^{t}\in\Theta}{\min}\quad\frac{1}{d_{k}}\sum_{X\in D_{k}}f_{L}(X;\theta_{k}^{t})+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}g_{i}(\theta_{k}^{t})},\vspace{-1mm} (5)

where gi(θkt),i∈{1,..,m}g_{i}(\theta_{k}^{{t}}),i\in\left\{1,..,m\right\} represents the it​hsubscript𝑖𝑡ℎi_{th} fairness constraint and λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} is a dual term that maximizes the objective function when the constraints are violated and relaxes the constraints when fairness goals are achieved. To solve this problem, a gradient-based approach is not viable due to the piecewise constant nature of the constraint functions in our scenario, resulting in near-zero gradients across most points. Utilizing a surrogate is an alternative, where indicators in Equation 4 are replaced with sigmoids for gradient-based optimization. While it resolves differentiability, a new issue emerges: Nash equilibrium aligns with solutions satisfying the sigmoid-relaxed constraint rather than the real one. To solve these issues, we approximate the penalty function through a maximization task. Specifically, we convert the Equation 5 into a min-max optimization problem:

m​a​xλi≥0​m​i​nθkt∈Θ​1dk​∑X∈DkfL​(X;θkt)+∑i=1mλi​gi​(θkt),subscript𝜆𝑖0𝑚𝑎𝑥superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡Θ𝑚𝑖𝑛1subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑋subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑓𝐿𝑋superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\footnotesize\begin{split}\footnotesize{\underset{\lambda_{i}\geq 0}{max}\quad\underset{\theta_{k}^{t}\in\Theta}{min}\quad\frac{1}{d_{k}}\sum_{X\in D_{k}}f_{L}(X;\theta_{k}^{t})+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}g_{i}(\theta_{k}^{t})},\end{split}\normalsize\vspace{-6mm} (6)

which converts the problem into a two-player zero-sum game. One player optimizes λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} to maximize the objective, while the other optimizes θktsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k}^{t} to minimize it. We optimize the inner minimization by taking the gradient to update the model weights:

θkt⁣∗←θkt−η​(1dk​∑X∈Dk∇fL​(X;θkt)+∑i=1mλi​∇gi​(θkt)).←subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝜂1subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑋subscript𝐷𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝐿𝑋superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖∇subscript𝑔𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\footnotesize{\theta^{t*}_{k}\leftarrow\theta^{t}_{k}-\eta(\frac{1}{d_{k}}\sum_{X\in D_{k}}\nabla f_{L}(X;\theta_{k}^{t})+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}\nabla g_{i}(\theta^{t}_{k}))}. (7)

Similarly, we update the dual term λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} through gradient ascent to penalize the constraint violations and promote constraint satisfaction:

λi∗←λi+η​(∇gi​(θkt⁣∗)).←superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖𝜂∇subscript𝑔𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\footnotesize{\lambda_{i}^{*}\leftarrow\lambda_{i}+\eta(\nabla g_{i}(\theta^{t*}_{k}))}. (8)

4.3 Global Fairness by Fairness-aware Clustering

Regular averaging aggregation methods, such as FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017), favor the clients that have more data points and frequently participate in the training, which potentially leads to a biased global model if these clients contribute biased local updates. In GLocalFair, we address this problem by clustering client updates based on their Gini coefficients Gini (1912), which are used for measuring inequality in the distribution of weights in the client update. We observe that biased models often exhibit skewed or imbalanced weight distributions due to imbalanced datasets or scenarios where specific parameters or features hold disproportionate significance, particularly under our local fairness constraints. As shown in Equations 7 and 8, the introduction of fairness constraints leads to penalties when violations occur, prompting adjustments in model weights to meet these constraints. A higher bias in the model results in more pronounced changes in λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}, consequently leading to more significant adjustments in model weights θktsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑡\theta_{k}^{t} and thereby disrupting its weight distribution. Hence, gauging model weight distributions could serve as a useful proxy for evaluating fairness within our proposed framework.

To better understand this, we plot Lorenz curves for four local model updates with corresponding Equalized Odds Difference (EOD) in Figure 3. Within biased models (clients 1 and 2), the Lorenz curves markedly diverge from the line of perfect equality, indicating the dominance of a limited subset of parameters in their weight distributions, while the Lorenz curve of relatively fair models (clients 3 and 4 with relatively lower EOD) would closely follow the line of perfect equality (empirical analysis is presented in Supplemental Material 12.1). We employ the Gini coefficient to provide an approximate measure of the fairness level within model updates. Subsequently, we employ K-means clustering to group client updates based on their Gini coefficients:

min​∑i=1p∑j=1ni‖𝒢i​j−1ni​∑j=1ni𝒢i​j‖2,superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptnormsubscript𝒢𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝒢𝑖𝑗2\footnotesize{\min\sum_{i=1}^{p}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}||\mathcal{G}_{ij}-\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\mathcal{G}_{ij}||^{2},}\vspace{-1mm} (9)

where 𝒢i​j=∑a=1w∑b=1w|Wi,j,at−Wi,j,bt|2​w2​W^i,jtsubscript𝒢𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑎1𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑗𝑎𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑗𝑏𝑡2superscript𝑤2superscriptsubscript^𝑊𝑖𝑗𝑡\mathcal{G}_{ij}=\frac{\sum_{a=1}^{w}\sum_{b=1}^{w}|W_{i,j,a}^{t}-W_{i,j,b}^{t}|}{2w^{2}\hat{W}_{i,j}^{t}} is the Gini coefficient of the j𝑗jth client in the i𝑖ith cluster. Wi,j,atsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑗𝑎𝑡W_{i,j,a}^{t} and Wi,j,btsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑗𝑏𝑡W_{i,j,b}^{t} represents the weights in j𝑗jth client’s model, and W^i​jtsuperscriptsubscript^𝑊𝑖𝑗𝑡\hat{W}_{ij}^{t} is the mean of all the weights while w𝑤w is the number of weights in the j𝑗jth client’s model. p𝑝p is the number of clusters determined by the elbow method, and nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is the number of clients in the it​hsubscript𝑖𝑡ℎi_{th} cluster. We then aggregate the updates using FedAvg with proportional weights at each cluster. The weight assigned to each client’s update is proportional to the number of samples they contributed during that round of training. Those aggregated updates are further aggregated based on the cumulative Gini coefficient of each cluster, favoring the fairer cluster. The resulting global model θg​l​o​b​a​lt+1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝑡1\theta_{global}^{t+1} can be obtained by:

θg​l​o​b​a​lt+1=θg​l​o​b​a​lt+∑i=1pe​x​p​(−γ​1ni​∑j=1ni𝒢i​j)​∑j=1nidi​j∑k=1nidi​k​θi​jt,superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝𝑒𝑥𝑝𝛾1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝒢𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑗𝑡\footnotesize{\theta_{global}^{t+1}=\theta_{global}^{t}+\sum_{i=1}^{p}exp(-\gamma\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\mathcal{G}_{ij})\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\frac{d_{ij}}{\sum_{k=1}^{n_{i}}d_{ik}}\theta_{ij}^{t},} (10)

where γ𝛾\gamma is a parameter that controls the degree of fairness. Note that when γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, the global model computed in Equation 10 is equivalent to that computed by FedAvg. di​jsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗d_{ij} denotes the number of data samples contributed by the j𝑗jth client in the i𝑖ith cluster. By reducing the influence of variations in updates across clients and prioritizing updates from clients with lower Gini coefficients (i.e., more fairness), our approach can promote fairness and reduce bias in the global model.

5 Experimental Evaluation

5.1 Experimental Setup

5.1.1 Federated Datasets

(1) CelebA Liu et al. (2018): A collection of 200​k200𝑘200k celebrity face images from that have been manually annotated. The dataset has up to 40 labels, each of which is binary-valued. We resize each image to 128128128×128128128px and create a classification task to classify whether the celebrity in the image is smiling or not. For CelebA, each subject’s gender (male or female) and age (young or adult) are the sensitive attributes.

(2) Adult Income Dua and Graff (2017): A tabular dataset that is widely investigated in ML fairness literature. It contains 48,8424884248,842 samples with 141414 attributes. We create a binary classifier to classify whether a subject’s income is above 50​k50𝑘50k or not. In this dataset, race (white or non-white) and gender (male or female) are used as the sensitive attributes.

(3) UTK Faces Zhang et al. (2017): A large-scale face dataset with more than 20,000 face images with annotations of age, gender, and ethnicity. The images cover large variations in pose, facial expression, illumination, occlusion, resolution, etc. We create a binary classification task of classifying young (less than 40 years) and old (older than 40 years). Here, race (white or non-white) and gender (male or female) are used as the sensitive attributes.

5.1.2 Evaluation Metric

(1) Equalized Odds Difference (EOD): We use EOD of each sensitive group to measure group fairness:

EOD=|Pr(Y^=1|Gg=0)−Pr(Y^=1|Gg=1)|g∈N.\footnotesize{\textup{EOD}=|Pr(\hat{Y}=1|G_{g}=0)-Pr(\hat{Y}=1|G_{g}=1)|_{g\in N}.} (11)

(2) Demographic Parity Disparity (DP-Dis): DP-Dis is another metric used for measuring group fairness, which is calculated as:

DP-Dis=maxg∈N|Pr(Y^=1|Gg=a)−Pr(Y^=1)|.\footnotesize{\textup{DP-Dis}=\underset{g\in N}{\max}\left|Pr(\hat{Y}=1|G_{g}=a)-Pr(\hat{Y}=1)\right|.} (12)

(3) Utility: In our experiments, we use the model’s prediction accuracy on the testing dataset as the metric to quantify global model utility.

(4) Discrepancy (DIS): To evaluate client fairness, we use the performance discrepancy among clients, which is measured as the difference between the highest and lowest accuracies on the clients.

Note that EOD and DP-Dis are common fairness metrics that have been widely used in the literature Zeng et al. (2022); Ezzeldin et al. (2023).

5.1.3 Parameter Selection

GLocalFair uses γ𝛾\gamma to control the balance between fairness and utility of the global model and (τFNR(\tau_{\textup{FNR}}, τFPR)\tau_{\textup{FPR}}) to adjust the local fairness constraint at the client’s side. Although a lower value for (τFNR(\tau_{\textup{FNR}}, τFPR)\tau_{\textup{FPR}}) can result in better FPR and FNR, it would also increase the risk of overconstraining the model and potentially converge to a trivial solution (e.g., a model that outputs same prediction for all inputs). To address this, we conducted preliminary experiments to explore different parameter values (presented in Supplemental Material 12.3) and empirically set γ𝛾\gamma to 0.60.60.6 for all datasets and (τFNR(\tau_{\textup{FNR}}, τFPR)\tau_{\textup{FPR}}) to (0.1,0.08)0.10.08(0.1,0.08), (0.1,0.08)0.10.08(0.1,0.08), and (0.06,0.06)0.060.06(0.06,0.06) for the CelebA, Adult Income, and UTK Faces datasets, respectively, to maintain good model utility.

5.1.4 Baselines

We compare GLocalFair with a set of state-of-the-art solutions, including a non-fairness method (FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017)), client-fairness methods (q-FFL Li et al. (2020) and GIFAIR Yue et al. (2023)), and group-fairness methods (FedFB Zeng et al. (2022) and FairFed Ezzeldin et al. (2023)).

(1) FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017): A common aggregation method for FL, where the client updates are weighted based on the number of the data samples in their local datasets. It does not account for any type of fairness.

(2) q-FFL Li et al. (2020): q-FFL is one of the client-fairness-based methods, aiming to equalize the accuracies of all the clients by dynamically reweighting the aggregation, favoring the clients with poor performance.

(3) GIFAIR Yue et al. (2023): GIFAIR aims to achieve client fairness using regularization term to penalize the spread in the loss.

(4) FedFB Zeng et al. (2022): FedFB is a group fairness method, where they have fitted the concept of fair batch from centralized learning into FL by leveraging the shared group-specific positive prediction rate for each client.

(5) FairFed Ezzeldin et al. (2023): FairFed is a group fairness method that can improve both local and group fairness. It employs FedAvg and a fairness-based reweighting mechanism to account for the mismatch between global fairness measure and local fairness measure.

5.2 Global Group Fairness

Table 1 shows the results of global group fairness (EOD and DP-Dis on the global test datasets) on the three datasets. As FairFed is limited to only a single binary sensitive group, to make a fair comparison, we run the federated training twice for all three datasets (once for each sensitive group) and report the EOD and the average DP-Dis of these training rounds. As we can see from the results, FedAvg, q-FFL, and GIFAIR perform poorly as their objective is not group fairness. As for the state-of-the-art group fairness solutions, FairFed and FedFB, we find that GLocalFair can outperform these solutions in all three datasets, with a significant global group fairness enhancement. Specifically, GLocalFair can improve EOD of gender and age by 44%percent4444\% and 41%percent4141\%, respectively, and improve DP-Dis by 34%percent3434\% compared to FedFB in CelebA. We observe a similar fairness improvement for the Adult Income and UTK Faces datasets. By jointly considering all the fairness metrics, GLocalFair achieves an overall 21%percent2121\% improvement compared to FedFB and 18%percent1818\% compared to FairFed in the Adult Income dataset. For the UTK Faces dataset, GLocalFair achieves 37%percent3737\% and 40%percent4040\% fairness improvements compared to FedFB and FairFed, respectively.

5.3 Local Group Fairness

To compare the local group fairness, we measure the mean and standard deviation of EOD and DP-Dis on individual clients. As shown in Table 2, we observe that the proposed GLocalFair is able to achieve a higher level of local group fairness compared to FairFed and FedFB with lower EOD and DP-Disparity values (in terms of both mean and standard deviation). Most noticeably, in the CelebA dataset, GLocalFair can achieve an average EOD of 0.150.150.15 for the gender group, which is 48%percent4848\% lower than FedFB with the second lowest measured EOD. To further visualize the distribution of local fairness measures across all clients, we compare the distribution of EOD and DP-Disparity with other group fairness methods in Figure 4. Note that for a completely fair model, the measured fairness metrics of clients should be of the same value and approach 00. We observe that the result of GLocalFair is more centered with lower variance, indicating better local group fairness. From the figure, we can observe that for gender groups in CelebA, almost 202020 out of 100100100 clients have near-zero EOD. Similarly, for DP-Dis in the CelebA dataset, most of the clients have less than a 0.20.20.2 disparity. These results demonstrate that by utilizing the proposed server-client co-design framework, GLocalFair can achieve greater local group fairness among the clients compared to other group fairness methods.

5.4 Utility and Client Fairness

From Table 1 and 2, we observe that the proposed GLocalFair offers competitive and stable performance in terms of maximizing the utility and mitigating discrepancy among the clients compared to other group-fairness-based methods. FedAvg achieves relatively higher model utility (e.g., the highest utility in the CelebA dataset) compared to other methods, which is expected as it is only optimized for utility and does not take fairness into account. Although the proposed GLocalFair is not optimized for client fairness, it can still outperform other group-fairness baselines (FedFB and FairFed). Specifically, as can be seen from Table 2, on the CelebA dataset, GLocalFair achieves an average performance improvement of 5%percent55\% and 7%percent77\% in discrepancy compared to FedFB and FairFed, respectively. Moreover, GLocalFair achieves 18%percent1818\% and 15%percent1515\% improvement on the Adult Income dataset and 6%percent66\% and 9.5%percent9.59.5\% on the UTK Faces dataset. These results show that GLocalFair can maintain a good level of model utility and client fairness while providing enhanced group fairness compared to other baselines.

5.5 Impact of Different FL Data Settings

To assess the robustness of our method to data heterogeneity, we perform experiments under different data distributions, including both IID and non-IID scenarios. We distribute the dataset among n𝑛n clients such that the distribution of sensitive attributes (G) is non-IID and can be controlled using a heterogeneity controller α𝛼\alpha, where α→∞→𝛼\alpha\rightarrow\infty corresponds to IID distributions. To create this heterogeneity, we use a power law distribution Clauset et al. (2009). The results in Table 3 show that while data heterogeneity has a significant impact on baseline methods, our method is immune to it due to the use of a clustering algorithm that helps to mitigate variance among client updates.

5.6 Interpretability

To examine model interpretability, we consider a binary classification task (i.e., smiling or not) on the CelebA dataset and compare the heat maps of the models produced by different FL framework baselines. We tested 202020 randomly selected images from the CelebA test set and generated the feature heat map using the Grad-CAM method Selvaraju et al. (2017). A visual comparison is provided in Figure 5, in which we observe that the heat maps of models from FedAvg, q-FFL, and GIFAIR mostly concentrate on regions of the human face (e.g., hair and eyes) that are closely related to sensitive demographic information such as gender or identity, which may introduce a bias towards certain groups. As FairFed and FedFB focus on removing bias on sensitive attributes in the model, we can see from the heat maps that they only concentrate on specific regions that are highly related to smiling, such as lips. However, FairFed concentrates on the forehead and FedFB concentrates on the hair. Emphasizing features from these areas can introduce a bias toward the age and gender of the subject. In the case of GLocalFair, we found that the heat map concentrates on less-biased areas of the human face, such as the chin, which indicates better model fairness compared to other methods.

6 Conclusion

We propose GLocalFair, a client-server co-design framework that mitigates the demographic biases while ensuring group fairness in FL at both global and local levels. We utilize constrained optimization to counter algorithmic biases on the client side and apply clustering-based aggregation on the server side for equitable global model performance among sensitive groups while preserving high utility. Our experiments across diverse datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves strong group fairness results globally and locally while also preserving utility similar to state-of-the-art fair FL frameworks.

7 GLocalFair Algorithm

The detailed steps performed on the server and clients in GLocalFair are summarized in Algorithm 1.

8 Convergence Rates

Theorem 1.

Define ℳℳ\mathcal{M} as the set of all stochastic (m+1)∗(m+1)𝑚1𝑚1(m+1)*(m+1) matrices, Λ:=Δm+1assignΛsuperscriptΔ𝑚1\Lambda:=\Delta^{m+1} as the (m+1)𝑚1(m+1) dimensional simplex, where m𝑚m is the number of functional constraints, and assume that each gi^^subscript𝑔𝑖\hat{g_{i}} upper bounds the corresponding gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} (gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} represents the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} constraint). The max-min formulation of Equation 6 in the paper uses a non-zero-sum two-player game where the λ𝜆\lambda-player chooses how much the θ𝜃\theta-player should penalize the (differentiable) sigmoid relaxed constraints but does so in such a way as to satisfy the original constraints. Let simplify the Equation 6 from the main paper as:

m​a​xλi≥0m​i​nθ∈ΘfL​(θ)+∑i=1mλi​gi​(θ),subscript𝜆𝑖0𝑚𝑎𝑥𝜃Θ𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝑓𝐿𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃\underset{\lambda_{i}\geq 0}{max}\quad\underset{\theta\in\Theta}{min}\quad f_{L}(\theta)+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}g_{i}(\theta), (13)

where fL​(θ)subscript𝑓𝐿𝜃f_{L}(\theta) is the binary cross-entropy loss that we want to minimize. Let denote the objective of two players (λ𝜆\lambda and θ𝜃\theta) as:

ℒθ​(θ,λ)=fL​(θ)+∑i=1mλi​gi​(θ),ℒλ​(θ,λ)=∑i=1mλi​gi​(θ),formulae-sequencesubscriptℒ𝜃𝜃𝜆subscript𝑓𝐿𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃subscriptℒ𝜆𝜃𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃\begin{split}\mathcal{L}_{\theta}(\theta,\lambda)&=f_{L}(\theta)+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}g_{i}(\theta),\\ \mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta,\lambda)&=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i}g_{i}(\theta),\end{split} (14)

where θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta and λ∈Λ𝜆Λ\lambda\in\Lambda jointly distributed random variables such that:

𝔼θ,λ​[ℒθ​(θ,λ)]−i​n​fθ∗∈Θ​𝔼λ​[ℒθ​(θ∗,λ)]≤ϵθ,m​a​xM∗∈ℳ​𝔼θ,λ​[ℒλ​(θ,M∗​λ)]−𝔼θ,λ​[ℒλ​(θ,λ)]≤ϵλ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼𝜃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptℒ𝜃𝜃𝜆superscript𝜃Θ𝑖𝑛𝑓subscript𝔼𝜆delimited-[]subscriptℒ𝜃superscript𝜃𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃superscript𝑀ℳ𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝔼𝜃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptℒ𝜆𝜃superscript𝑀𝜆subscript𝔼𝜃𝜆delimited-[]subscriptℒ𝜆𝜃𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜆\begin{split}&\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\mathcal{L}_{\theta}(\theta,\lambda)]-\underset{\theta^{*}\in\Theta}{inf}\mathbb{E}_{\lambda}[\mathcal{L}_{\theta}(\theta^{*},\lambda)]\leq\epsilon_{\theta},\\ &\underset{M^{*}\in\mathcal{M}}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta,M^{*}\lambda)]-\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta,\lambda)]\leq\epsilon_{\lambda}.\end{split} (15)

Suppose θ¯¯𝜃\bar{\theta} is a random variable for which θ¯=θt¯𝜃superscript𝜃𝑡\bar{\theta}=\theta^{t} with probability λ1t/∑s=1Tλ1ssuperscriptsubscript𝜆1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑠1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜆1𝑠\lambda_{1}^{t}/\sum_{s=1}^{T}\lambda_{1}^{s} and let λ¯:=(∑t=1Tλt)/Tassign¯𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝜆𝑡𝑇\bar{\lambda}:=\left(\sum_{t=1}^{T}\lambda^{t}\right)/T, then θ¯¯𝜃\bar{\theta} represents a sub-optimal solution when:

𝔼θ¯​[fL​(θ¯)]≤i​n​fθ∗∈Θ:∀i.g^i(θ∗)≤0​fL​(θ∗)+ϵθ+ϵλλ¯1,\mathbb{E}_{\bar{\theta}}[f_{L}(\bar{\theta})]\leq\underset{\theta^{*}\in\Theta:\forall_{i}.\hat{g}_{i}(\theta^{*})\leq 0}{inf}f_{L}(\theta^{*})+\frac{\epsilon_{\theta}+\epsilon_{\lambda}}{\bar{\lambda}_{1}},\\ (16)

and it is a nearly-feasible solution when:

m​a​xi∈[m]​𝔼θ¯​[gi​(θ¯)]≤ϵλλ¯1.𝑖delimited-[]𝑚𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝔼¯𝜃delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑖¯𝜃subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜆subscript¯𝜆1\underset{i\in[m]}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\bar{\theta}}[g_{i}(\bar{\theta})]\leq\frac{\epsilon_{\lambda}}{\bar{\lambda}_{1}}. (17)

Note that the optimality inequality is weaker than it may appear since the comparator in this equation is not the optimal solution w.r.t. the constraints gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i}, but rather w.r.t. the sigmoid constraints g^isubscript^𝑔𝑖\hat{g}_{i}.

Proof.

Optimality: If we choose M∗superscript𝑀M^{*} to be a matrix with its first row being all-one and all other rows being all-zero, then ℒ​(θ,M∗​λ)=0ℒ𝜃superscript𝑀𝜆0\mathcal{L}(\theta,M^{*}\lambda)=0, which shows that the first term in the LHS of the second line of Equation 15 is non-negative. 𝔼θ,λ​(∑i=1mλi+1​g^i​(θ))≥−ϵλ.subscript𝔼𝜃𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖1subscript^𝑔𝑖𝜃subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜆\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i+1}\hat{g}_{i}(\theta)\right)\geq-\epsilon_{\lambda}.\\ (18)

Here, ℒθsubscriptℒ𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\theta} is linear in λ𝜆\lambda, so the first line of the Equation 15, combined with the above results and the definition of ℒθsubscriptℒ𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\theta}, becomes:

𝔼θ,λ​[λ1​fL​(θ)]−i​n​fθ∗∈Θ​(λ¯1​fL​(θ∗)+∑i=1mλi+1​g^i​(θ∗))≤ϵθ+ϵλ.subscript𝔼𝜃𝜆delimited-[]subscript𝜆1subscript𝑓𝐿𝜃superscript𝜃Θ𝑖𝑛𝑓subscript¯𝜆1subscript𝑓𝐿superscript𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜆𝑖1subscript^𝑔𝑖superscript𝜃subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜆\footnotesize\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\lambda_{1}f_{L}(\theta)]-\underset{\theta^{*}\in\Theta}{inf}\left(\bar{\lambda}_{1}f_{L}(\theta^{*})+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lambda_{i+1}\hat{g}_{i}(\theta^{*})\right)\leq\epsilon_{\theta}+\epsilon_{\lambda}.\\ (19)

Suppose θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*} is the optimal solution that satisfies the sigmoid constraints g^^𝑔\hat{g}, so that g^i​(θ∗)≤0subscript^𝑔𝑖superscript𝜃0\hat{g}_{i}(\theta^{*})\leq 0 for all i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], then we can have:

which is the optimality claim.

Feasibility: To simplify the notation, suppose l1​(θ):=0assignsubscript𝑙1𝜃0l_{1}(\theta):=0 and li+1​(θ):=gi​(θ)assignsubscript𝑙𝑖1𝜃subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃l_{i+1}(\theta):=g_{i}(\theta) for i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], then ℒλ​(θ,λ)=⟨λ,l​(θ)⟩subscriptℒ𝜆𝜃𝜆𝜆𝑙𝜃\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta,\lambda)=\langle\lambda,l(\theta)\rangle. Consider the first term in LHS of the second line of Equation 15:

m​a​xM∗∈ℳ𝔼θ,λ[ℒλ(θ,M∗λ)]=m​a​xM∗∈ℳ𝔼θ,λ[⟨M∗λ,l(θ)⟩],=m​a​xM∗∈ℳ​𝔼θ,λ​[∑i=1m+1∑j=1m+1Mj,i∗​λi,lj​(θ)],=∑i=1m+1m​a​xj∈[m+1]​𝔼θ,λ​[λi​lj​(θ)],\begin{split}\underset{M^{*}\in\mathcal{M}}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[&\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta,M^{*}\lambda)]=\underset{M^{*}\in\mathcal{M}}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\langle M^{*}\lambda,l(\theta)\rangle],\\ &=\underset{M^{*}\in\mathcal{M}}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{m+1}\sum_{j=1}^{m+1}M^{*}_{j,i}\lambda_{i},l_{j}(\theta)\right],\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^{m+1}\underset{j\in[m+1]}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\lambda_{i}l_{j}(\theta)],\end{split} (21)

where we used the fact that since M∗superscript𝑀M^{*} is left-stochastic, each of its columns is an (m+1)-dimensional mulitinoulli distribution. For the second term in the LHS of the second line of Equation 15, we can use the fact that l1​(θ)=0subscript𝑙1𝜃0l_{1}(\theta)=0:

𝔼θ,λ​[∑i=2m+1λi​li​(θ)]≤∑i=2m+1m​a​xj∈[m+1]​𝔼θ,λ​[λi​lj​(θ)].subscript𝔼𝜃𝜆delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑚1subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑙𝑖𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑚1𝑗delimited-[]𝑚1𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝔼𝜃𝜆delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑙𝑗𝜃\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}\left[\sum_{i=2}^{m+1}\lambda_{i}l_{i}(\theta)\right]\leq\sum_{i=2}^{m+1}\underset{j\in[m+1]}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\lambda_{i}l_{j}(\theta)].\\ (22)

Plugging these two results into the second line of Equation 15, the two sums collapse, leaving:

m​a​xi∈[m+1]​𝔼θ,λ​[λ1​li​(θ)]≤ϵλ.𝑖delimited-[]𝑚1𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝔼𝜃𝜆delimited-[]subscript𝜆1subscript𝑙𝑖𝜃subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜆\underset{i\in[m+1]}{max}\mathbb{E}_{\theta,\lambda}[\lambda_{1}l_{i}(\theta)]\leq\epsilon_{\lambda}.\\ (23)

Given the definition of lisubscript𝑙𝑖l_{i}, we can yield the feasibility claim. ∎

Corollary 1.

Let f1,f2,…:Θ→ℝ:subscript𝑓1subscript𝑓2…→Θℝf_{1},f_{2},...:\Theta\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be a sequence of convex functions that we wish to minimize on a compact convex set ΘΘ\Theta. Let the step size η=BΘBΔ^​2​T𝜂subscript𝐵Θsubscript𝐵^Δ2𝑇\eta=\frac{B_{\Theta}}{B_{\hat{\Delta}\sqrt{2T}}} where BΘ≥m​a​xθ∈Θ​∥θ∥2subscript𝐵Θ𝑚𝑎subscript𝑥𝜃Θsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜃2B_{\Theta}\geq max_{\theta\in\Theta}\lVert\theta\rVert_{2} and BΔ^≥∥Δt^∥2subscript𝐵^Δsubscriptdelimited-∥∥^superscriptΔ𝑡2B_{\hat{\Delta}}\geq\lVert\hat{\Delta^{t}}\rVert_{2} is a uniform upper bound on the norms of stochastic subgradients. Suppose that we perform T𝑇T iterations of the following stochastic update starting from θ1=a​r​g​m​i​nθ∈Θ​∥θ∥2superscript𝜃1𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑚𝑖subscript𝑛𝜃Θsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜃2\theta^{1}=argmin_{\theta\in\Theta}\lVert\theta\rVert_{2}:

θt+1=ΠΘ​(θt−η​Δ^t),superscript𝜃𝑡1subscriptΠΘsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝜂superscript^Δ𝑡\theta^{t+1}=\Pi_{\Theta}\left(\theta^{t}-\eta\hat{\Delta}^{t}\right),\\ (24)

where 𝔼​[Δ^t|θt]∈t(θt)subscript𝑡𝔼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscript^Δ𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡\mathbb{E}[\hat{\Delta}^{t}|\theta^{t}]\in_{t}(\theta^{t}), i.e. Δ^tsuperscript^Δ𝑡\hat{\Delta}^{t} is a stochastic subgradient of ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t} at θtsuperscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{t} and ΠΘsubscriptΠΘ\Pi_{\Theta} projects its arguments onto ΘΘ\Theta w.r.t. the Euclidean norm. Then with probability 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta over the draws of the stochastic subgradients:

1T​∑t=1Tft​(θt)−1T​∑t=1Tft​(θ∗)≤2​BΘ​BΔ^​1+16​l​n​1δT,1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑓𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑓𝑡superscript𝜃2subscript𝐵Θsubscript𝐵^Δ116𝑙𝑛1𝛿𝑇\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}f_{t}(\theta^{t})-\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}f_{t}(\theta^{*})\leq 2B_{\Theta}B_{\hat{\Delta}}\sqrt{\frac{1+16ln\frac{1}{\delta}}{T}},\\ (25)

where θ∗∈Θsuperscript𝜃Θ\theta^{*}\in\Theta is an arbitrary reference vector.

Lemma 1.

Suppose that ΘΘ\Theta is a compact convex set and the objective, and sigmoid constraint functions g^1,….,g^m\hat{g}_{1},....,\hat{g}_{m} are convex (but not g1,….,gmg_{1},....,g_{m}). The three upper bounds are BΘ≥m​a​xθ∈Θ​∥θ∥2subscript𝐵Θ𝑚𝑎subscript𝑥𝜃Θsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜃2B_{\Theta}\geq max_{\theta\in\Theta}\lVert\theta\rVert_{2}, BΔ^≥m​a​xt∈T​∥Δ^t∥2subscript𝐵^Δ𝑚𝑎subscript𝑥𝑡𝑇subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript^Δ𝑡2B_{\hat{\Delta}}\geq max_{t\in T}\lVert\hat{\Delta}^{t}\rVert_{2} and BΔ≥m​a​xt∈T​∥Δλt∥∞subscript𝐵Δ𝑚𝑎subscript𝑥𝑡𝑇subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆𝑡B_{\Delta}\geq max_{t\in T}\lVert\Delta_{\lambda}^{t}\rVert_{\infty}. If we run the client side optimization with step size ηθ:=BΘ/BΔ^​2​Tassignsubscript𝜂𝜃subscript𝐵Θsubscript𝐵^Δ2𝑇\eta_{\theta}:=B_{\Theta}/B_{\hat{\Delta}\sqrt{2T}} and ηλ:=(m+1)​l​n​(m+1)/T​BΔ2assignsubscript𝜂𝜆𝑚1𝑙𝑛𝑚1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐵Δ2\eta_{\lambda}:=\sqrt{(m+1)ln(m+1)/TB_{\Delta}^{2}}, then the results would satisfy the conditions of Theorem 1 for:

ϵθ=2​BΘ​BΔ^​1+16​l​n​2δT,ϵλ=2​BΔ​2​(m+1)​l​n​(m+1)​(1+16​l​n​2δ)T,formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃2subscript𝐵Θsubscript𝐵^Δ116𝑙𝑛2𝛿𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜆2subscript𝐵Δ2𝑚1𝑙𝑛𝑚1116𝑙𝑛2𝛿𝑇\begin{split}&\epsilon_{\theta}=2B_{\Theta}B_{\hat{\Delta}}\sqrt{\frac{1+16ln\frac{2}{\delta}}{T}},\\ &\epsilon_{\lambda}=2B_{\Delta}\sqrt{\frac{2(m+1)ln(m+1)(1+16ln\frac{2}{\delta})}{T}},\end{split} (26)

with probability 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta over the draws of stochastic subgradients.

Proof.

By applying Corollary 1 to the optimization over θ𝜃\theta and with probability 1−2​δ′12superscript𝛿′1-2\delta^{\prime} over the stochastic subgradients, we can get:

1T∑t=1Tℒθ(θt,λt)−1T∑t=1Tℒθ(θ∗,λt)≤2​BΘ​BΔ^​1+16​l​n​1δ′T,1T∑t=1Tℒλ(θt,M∗λt)−1T∑t=1Tℒλ(θ∗,λt)≤2​BΔ​2​(m+1)​l​n​(m+1)​(1+16​l​n​2δ)T.formulae-sequence1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscriptℒ𝜃superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜆𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscriptℒ𝜃superscript𝜃superscript𝜆𝑡2subscript𝐵Θsubscript𝐵^Δ116𝑙𝑛1superscript𝛿′𝑇1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscriptℒ𝜆superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝑀superscript𝜆𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscriptℒ𝜆superscript𝜃superscript𝜆𝑡2subscript𝐵Δ2𝑚1𝑙𝑛𝑚1116𝑙𝑛2𝛿𝑇\begin{split}\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\theta}(\theta^{t},&\lambda^{t})-\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\theta}(\theta^{*},\lambda^{t})\leq\\ &2B_{\Theta}B_{\hat{\Delta}}\sqrt{\frac{1+16ln\frac{1}{\delta^{\prime}}}{T}},\\ \frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta^{t},&M^{*}\lambda^{t})-\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta^{*},\lambda^{t})\leq\\ &2B_{\Delta}\sqrt{\frac{2(m+1)ln(m+1)(1+16ln\frac{2}{\delta})}{T}}.\end{split} (27)

By taking δ=2​δ′𝛿2superscript𝛿′\delta=2\delta^{\prime} and using the definitions of θ¯¯𝜃\bar{\theta} and λ¯¯𝜆\bar{\lambda}, we can yield the claimed result. ∎

9 Federated Datasets

We evaluate the proposed GLocalFair using the following three datasets:

(1) CelebA Liu et al. [2018]: A collection of 200​k200𝑘200k celebrity face images from the Internet that have been manually annotated. The dataset has up to 40 labels, each of which is binary-valued. We resize each image to 128128128×128128128px and create a classification task to classify whether the celebrity in the image is smiling or not. For CelebA, each subject’s gender (male or female) and age (young or adult) are considered sensitive attributes. We sort the images by the celebrity ID according to Caldas et al. Caldas et al. [2018]. This results in a dataset with a total number of 200,288200288200,288 images from 9,34393439,343 celebrities. The dataset is then randomly partitioned for training and testing with no overlapping celebrity ID, each containing 180,429180429180,429 images from 8,40884088,408 celebrities and 19,8591985919,859 images from 935935935 celebrities, respectively. Finally, the training dataset is randomly distributed into 100100100 silos with no overlapping celebrity ID to emulate the cross-silo FL setup. In addition, in each silo, we randomly split the image data in a 70-10-20 manner, where 70%percent7070\% of the data are used for training, 10%percent1010\% are used for validating constrained optimization, and 20%percent2020\% are reserved for testing client fairness.

(2) Adult Income Dua and Graff [2017]: A tabular dataset that is widely investigated in machine learning fairness literature. It contains 48,8424884248,842 samples with 141414 attributes. We create a binary classifier to classify whether a subject’s income is above 50​k50𝑘50k or not. In this dataset, race (white or non-white) and gender (male or female) are used as the sensitive attributes. We keep 10%percent1010\% of the remaining dataset for testing the global model. We distribute the rest of the dataset among four clients where each client holds one of the four possible combinations (i.e., white male, nonwhite male, white female, and non-white female) of two sensitive groups. Clients use the same 70-10-20 data split as the previous dataset.

(3) UTK Faces Zhang et al. [2017]: A large-scale face dataset with more than 20,000 face images with annotations of age, gender, and ethnicity. The images cover large variations in pose, facial expression, illumination, occlusion, resolution, etc. We resize each image to 128128128×128128128px and create a binary classification task of classifying young (less than 40 years) and old (older than 40 years). Here, race (white or non-white) and gender (male or female) are used as the sensitive attributes. We divide the dataset into 90% training and 10% testing data. We randomly distributed the training dataset to 20 clients where each client’s data quantity has a mean of 900 and a variance of 250.

10 Model Description

We evaluate GLocalFair on three datasets, namely, CelebA, Adult Income, and UTK Faces. The details of the FL model used for each dataset are presented below:

  1. (1)

    CelebA: We train a Resnet34 He et al. [2016] model with a single fully connected layer, equipped with a sigmoid activation function for binary classification (i.e., classifying whether the celebrity in the image is smiling or not). The input layer is modified to accommodate the image dimensions of 128x128 pixels, characteristic of the CelebA dataset to reduce the computation cost at the clients. We use Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.010.010.01 with 10%percent1010\% decay rate.

  2. (2)

    Adult Income: We use a Multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) model containing two hidden layers, each with 32 and 16 units, respectively, and a single unit output layer for binary classification (i.e., classifying whether a subject’s income is above 50k or not). We use SGD with a learning rate of 0.010.010.01 and momentum of 0.90.90.9

  3. (3)

    UTK Faces: We train a MobileNetV2 Sandler et al. [2018] model with an input size of 128128128x128128128. We use Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.050.050.05 with 10%percent1010\% decay rate.

11 Federated Learning Settings

In our evaluation, we adjust the FL setup in each dataset to accommodate data from different genres. For datasets with fewer clients, we choose to use a higher client participation rate.

  1. (1)

    CelebA: We use 100100100 clients to train the model for 150150150 communication rounds with a client participation rate of 0.30.30.3 and a γ𝛾\gamma value of 0.60.60.6.

  2. (2)

    Adult Income: We use 444 clients to train the model for 303030 communication rounds with a client participation rate of 0.750.750.75 and a γ𝛾\gamma value of 0.60.60.6.

  3. (3)

    UTK Faces: We use 202020 clients to train the model for 150150150 communication rounds with a client participation rate of 0.40.40.4 and a γ𝛾\gamma value of 0.60.60.6.

12 Additional Evaluation

12.1 Group Fairness vs. Gini Coefficients

We conduct experiments on the CelebA dataset to investigate the relationship between the fairness of client model updates and their Gini Coefficients, which are calculated to measure the distribution inequality of their model weights and are used as a proxy of group fairness in this paper. To empirically show the relationship between group fairness and Gini Coefficients of model updates, we analyze and visualize the Gini Coefficient values for each client’s update during the 15​t​h15𝑡ℎ15th training round and the final training round (150​t​h150𝑡ℎ150th) in relation to their EOD values (i.e., one of the group fairness metrics we use in the paper) of each client’s model in Figure 6. Our observations reveal a strong correlation between the Gini Coefficient and EOD values. Specifically, clients whose models exhibited higher EOD values also displayed higher Gini Coefficients. This alignment suggests that biased models are typically associated with unevenly distributed model weights under our proposed local fairness constraints. Conversely, clients whose models boasted lower EOD values showcased lower Gini Coefficients, indicating a more equitable distribution of model weights. As the fairness of the models improved at the end of the training, as evidenced by lower EOD values, the Gini coefficients of these models also reduced.

12.2 Benefits of Two Fold Fairness Optimization in GLocalFair

We embrace a dual-fold strategy for fairness optimization. This strategy encompasses both local and global dimensions of fairness. The first facet of our approach focuses on attaining local fairness by integrating a local fairness constraint optimization mechanism at the client level. Complementing this, the second facet of our approach addresses global fairness through a distinctive methodology that employs fairness-aware clustering-based aggregation on the server side. This server-level operation aspires to harmonize the contributions from diverse clients, ensuring that the aggregation process mitigates the amplification of any inherent disparities. To rigorously assess the efficacy of these individual fairness enhancement methods, we conducted an additional experiment using the CelebA dataset. Specifically, the experiment aims to evaluate the unique contributions of each strategy (client-level or server-level) to the overall fairness improvement. We use FedAvg on the server for aggregation when we use local fairness constraint optimization only. In Table 4, we show the results of local fairness constraint optimization and the fairness-aware clustering-based aggregation individually. As we can observe from the table, the global fairness measured on the global model is lower when we employ only the local fairness constraints on the client side, but it gets improved when fairness-aware clustering is used, showing the local fairness improvement does not fully improve the global fairness. Similarly, when the local fairness constraints are used, the local fairness is improved, but the discrepancy among the client’s performance is degraded due to the use of FedAvg on the server side. Local fairness is degraded when only the fairness-aware clustering is used on the server side, but the discrepancy among the client’s performance is improved. When we combine both the fairness strategies in GLocalFair, they complement each other and improve both local and global group fairness.

12.3 Impact of Client Fairness Constraint

At each client, we use constraint optimization on top of the learning algorithm to enforce local fairness. In each round of training, we constrain the false positive rate (FPR) and false negative rate (FNR) and use a misclassification penalty for constraint violations. We evaluate GLocalFair with different τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} values (i.e., 0.08, 0.10, 0.15, and 0.20) and a fixed τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} value (i.e., 0.100.100.10) on the CelebA dataset in Table 5. We observe that it achieves the best performance when τF​P​R=0.08subscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅0.08\tau_{FPR}=0.08. Although further decreasing τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} may seemingly increase performance, in our experiments, we find that any τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} values smaller than 0.080.080.08 would result in a trivial model that outputs the same prediction for all data samples. On the other hand, if we increase τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} to be larger than 0.150.150.15, there would be almost no effect of constraint as the model will converge with an FPR value lower than the limit. We also test a few combinations with varying τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR}. We find that with τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} fixed, using a smaller τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} value can help improve model fairness. However, if we set both τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} and τF​P​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑃𝑅\tau_{FPR} to 0.080.080.08, it over-constraints the model and makes it unstable. Also, any value larger than 0.150.150.15 for τF​N​Rsubscript𝜏𝐹𝑁𝑅\tau_{FNR} has almost no effect on the model performance.

12.4 Local Group Fairness for the Adult Income and UTK Faces Datasets

Figure 7 compares the local fairness (i.e., distribution of EOD and DP-Dis among individual clients) of GLocalFair with FedFB and FairFed on the Adult Income and UTK Faces dataset. Note that for a completely fair model, the measured fairness metrics of clients should be of the same value and approach 00. We observe that the result of GLocalFair is more centered with lower variance, indicating better local group fairness. Especially for the UTK Faces gender groups (Figure 7(b)), almost 171717 out of 202020 clients have near-zero EOD. Similar results can be observed for DP-Dis in the UTK Faces dataset as most of the clients have less than 0.30.30.3 disparity. For the Adult Income dataset, we also observe that GLocalFair has the highest number of clients that achieve the lowest EOD and DP-Dis. These results demonstrate that by utilizing the proposed server-client co-design framework, GLocalFair can achieve greater local group fairness among the clients compared to other group fairness methods.

12.5 Fairness vs. Utility Trade-off

In the design of GLocalFair, we use γ𝛾\gamma to control the balance between fairness and utility of the global model. A larger γ𝛾\gamma value would result in a fairer model with lower utility. We evaluate GLocalFair with different γ𝛾\gamma values on the CelebA dataset and summarize the results in Table 6.We can observe that as γ𝛾\gamma increases, the utility of the model decreases while the fairness performance saturates at γ=0.6𝛾0.6\gamma=0.6. Therefore, we set γ=0.6𝛾0.6\gamma=0.6 in our major experiments, which ensures the model’s fairness while still maintaining a good level of utility.

12.6 Customizable Fairness Configuration on Client Models

The developed GLocalFair offers customizable fairness configurations on the client side, aiming to cater to diverse fairness requirements. To evaluate this feature, we intentionally alternate between fixing the FPR and FNR while relaxing the other fairness constraint, mirroring real-world scenarios where a preference for lower FPR or FNR varies. As shown in Table 7, across all scenarios, we observe consistently high utility scores. constraining FPR results in high precision values, around 0.95, indicating accurate positive predictions. However, this often leads to a lower recall due to the unconstrained FNR, resulting in a higher number of false negatives. Conversely, when FNR is constrained, recall is notably high, signifying comprehensive positive predictions. Nevertheless, in these instances, precision tends to be lower due to the unconstrained FPR, which results in a higher number of false positives. These findings underscore the importance and effectiveness of customizable fairness configurations in GLocalFair, as they enable the adaptation of model behavior to varying fairness requirements and real-world scenarios.

12.7 Additional Interpretability Results

In Figure 8, we extend the interpretability analysis of each baseline method using the CelebA dataset. Specifically, we show three examples from both classes (smiling and not smiling). From the visualization results, it is clear that GLocalFair focuses on the areas that contain less sensitive attributes, which makes it fairer over the demographic groups compared to other baselines.
